item.title: ARC Raiders Final Open Beta Server Slam Test—Start Date, How To Play & Platforms
item.content:encoded:
If you can’t bear to wait a few more days, one final ARC Raiders Open Beta test awaits. It’s known as the ‘Server Slam Test,’ and it’s trying to ascertain server stability and functionality. Check out its dates and how you can take part in the final hurdle before launch.

There are no more ARC Raiders delays on the cards. We know the devs thought the game was “Not Fun,” hence earlier delays. We are now about as locked in as you’ll need to be once you set foot in Speranza and the surface for real this time. But just in case, Embark Studios has unleashed one final open beta test for ARC Raiders.

It’s a server stress test to find out how many players are likely to pop in on release day, and how the servers will handle the enormous amount of pressure likely heading the shooter’s way.

When Does The ARC Raiders Final Open Beta Server Slam Test Start?

The concluding ARC Raiders Open Beta will begin on October 17, and you’ve got until October 19 to see what the extraction shooter is all about heading into launch.

It’s only a short one, but it’s both a final chance to see if ARC Raiders is for you (it’s basically a free demo), and this is your moment to let Embark Studios know if anything needs fixing, improving, or looking at before October 30.

How To Play ARC Raiders Server Slam Test

The ARC Raiders Sever Slam Test is a fully open beta, meaning anyone can download and play it. You don’t need to obtain a code and redeem it, nor do you need to pre-order ARC Raiders.

“No codes this time. Everyone’s welcome,” says the developer on Steam.

The only thing to do on your end is to download the open beta to your format, and prepare yourself for more chaos—speaking of which.

All ARC Raiders Final Open Beta Server Slam Test Platforms

You can download the ARC Raiders Server Slam Test on PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC through Steam and the Epic Games Store.

It’s a current-gen release for ARC Raiders: No PS4, Xbox One, or Switch versions. If you meet the criteria for the beta, you can download and play from October 17.

Do note: Any progress you make in the ARC Raiders Server Slam Open Beta Test won’t carry over to the full game.

Given how close we are to launch, will you wait for ARC Raiders’ full release? Or is the wait proving to be so gut-wrenching that playing in the ARC Raiders Final Open Beta Server Slam Test a given? You know what to do: Talk all things ARC Raiders via the Insider Gaming Forum.

For more on the shooter, read about ARC Raiders having optional progression wipes, if it has crossplay, and if it’s coming to Xbox Game Pass.

item.title: Pokémon Scarlet/Violet DLC Cost as Much to Make as Legends: Arceus, Leaks Reveal
item.content:encoded:
New leaks have revealed that Pokémon Scarlet/Violet’s cost went way over budget, matching the likes of Pokémon Legends: Arceus’ entire development.

A massive number of leaks have surfaced online about the Pokémon franchise since yesterday, revealing details about past, present, and future games. We have already been informed about the Gen 10 title, Wind and Wave, and a roadmap for future Pokémon games. Now, new details about Scarlet and Violet’s DLC have also surfaced online.

Pokémon Scarlet and Violet’s Expansion Brought In 6.15 Million Downloads

As revealed by the reliable CentroLeaks on X (formerly Twitter), the cost for Pokémon Scarlet and Violet’s DLC development surpassed their estimated budgets enormously, reaching “as much as the entire Legends: Arceus development”. After that, the development team decided that DLCs would be kept “at an appropriate scale commensurate with the revenue, and focus on achieving low costs”. In the first 10 months, the DLC sold 6.15 million downloads, which is 25% of the players that own the game.

DLCs Became a Mandate After Pokémon Scarlet and Violet’s Expansion

A previous post from Centro also talks about troubles during the development of the Pokémon Scarlet and Violet DLC, which led to a decision that many fans will be happy about. It seems that the DLC was not planned from the beginning, which led to a bug that affected development. After this issue, “Game Freak mandated that all future games will be programmed assuming DLC will be made.” Which means all future Pokémon games will be made with an expansion in mind.

item.title: Pokémon Legends: Z-A Season 1 Ranked—Release Date, Start Time & Rewards
item.content:encoded:
If you can’t wait to get stuck into Pokémon Legends: Z-A Season 1’s Ranked mode, you need to hear about its official start date, what time it’s expected to go live, and potential rewards waiting for you if you can be the very best like no one ever was.

Pokémon Legends: Z-A has a different feel to Arceus. From its location to its gameplay mechanics, there are differences across the board. But we’ve not had to wait for the game’s launch to find out everything about the RPG. We already know the complete Pokémon Legends: Z-A Pokédex and its file size.

The developer is also keen to keep you all up to date with Season 1 Ranked—and so are we!

You can write down October 16 in your diary as the start date for Z-A Season 1’s Ranked mode.

Funnily enough, it coincides with the game’s release day! Many new releases wait until some time after launch before going full board with any Season 1 content. If you’re looking forward to Pokémon Legends: Z-A’s Ranked content, you won’t have to wait long to get stuck in.

Pokémon has revealed that 6:00 UTC is the official start time for Season 1 Ranked.

Here’s a quick time breakdown of what this looks like for different regions if you’re having trouble converting UTC to your time zone.

So far, we know you can earn a Greninjite for ranking up in Season 1.

Obviously, there will be a lot more to earn, which we’ll learn about once Season 1 is live. The more battling you do, and the more you win, the better your loot at the end of it!

item.title: Call of Duty Exists Because “EA Were D***s”, Says Vince Zampella
item.content:encoded:
The current lead for the Battlefield franchise has stated that the only reason Call of Duty exists is because EA had a fallout with him.

The Battlefield franchise is back to its victory days with the release of BF6, finally giving the likes of Call of Duty some serious competition. Their last title, Battlefield 2042, didn’t perform well with fans, but the developers have pulled off a complete turnaround, with BF6 reaching almost 750k concurrent players on launch day.

Vince Zampella Reveals Call of Duty is Only Here Because ‘EA Were D***s’

During a new interview with GQ (via GamesRadar+), Vince Zampella spoke about Call of Duty’s existence. The executive vice president at Electronic Arts stated, “The only reason that Call of Duty exists is because EA were dicks”. For those unaware about Zampella’s past, he left EA after a dispute, only to make Infinity Ward in 2002, which led to the creation of the Call of Duty franchise. He later returned to EA to oversee games such as Titanfall, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, and Apex Legends.

Vince Zampella is a true veteran of the shooter genre, delivering players with some of the biggest hits in this space. He started with Medal of Honor: Allied Assault, where we worked closely with Steven Spielberg. After the dispute, Activision tasked him with creating a franchise that would kill Medal of Honor, and that was Call of Duty. However, after that, he returned to EA and is now overseeing the latest big thing in the FPS space, Battlefield.

In other news, Battlefield 6’s campaign offers players an uninstall button after completion. Additionally, Black Ops 7 beta matches were nearly 99% cheater-free.
